titleStmt.title: A garden of flovvers vvherein very liuely is contained a true and perfect discription of al the flovvers contained in these foure followinge bookes. As also the perfect true manner of colouringe the same vvith theire naturall coloures ... All vvhich to the great charges, and almost incredible laboure and paine, the diligent authore by foure yeares experience, hath very laboriously compiled, and most excellently performed, both in theire perfect lineaments in representing them in theire coper plates: as also after a most exquisite manner and methode in teachinge the practisioner te [sic] painte them even to the liffe. Faithfully and truely translated out of the Netherlandish originall into English for the comon benifite of those that vnderstand no other languages, and also for the benifite of others nevvly printed both in the Latine and French tongues all at the charges of the author.
Hortus floridus. English

notesStmt.note: Dedication signed: Crispian de passe Iunior.
A translation by Thomas Wood or E.W. of: Hortus floridus.
"The booke to his readers" is signed by Thomas Wood; the translator's dedication to book four is signed: E.W.

In two parts, the first containing four books according to the seasons. Part 2, "Altera pars horti floridi" has divisional title and an engraved Biblical text ([2] leaves) followed by 62 leaves of plates with letterpress Latin descriptions on facing pages.
Several plates in part 1, books 1 and 2 are signed by Simon van de Pass and Willem van de Passe.

First part letterpress signatures: A-GÂ² , all in English. These leaves were evidently intended to be dispersed through part 1, quires A-C having the general preliminaries and the text for book 1 (spring), quire D having the text for book 2 (summer), E1-F1 for book 3 (autumn), and F2-G2 for book 4 (winter). Some copies may have additional letterpress leaves with text in other languages.

Copies vary in the number of plates in part 1, and plates may have letterpress Latin text on versos. For book 1 originally 41 flower plates (some unnumbered) and one "garden" plate were engraved (the latter with legend "Meridies" at top but other directions not labeled); later 12 plates numbered 43-54 were added. Book 2 originally had 19 plates; later a plate 20 was added, and another copy of the "garden" plate may be present. Book 3 has 26 numbered plates (two numbered 25) plus a "garden" plate with "Meridies" at top and the other three directions also labeled; book 4 has 12 numbered plates and possibly a duplicate of the second "garden" plate.
For more details on states see "The Library", ser. 4, vol. 4 (1924), p. 181-206.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the Reader Salute.
div.p: FOr the avoydinge of all confuÅ¿ion, I haue thought it good. (gentle Reader) in this deÅ¿cription of the Coloures, to follovv the order of the flovvers, like as they are noted and marked by theire Cypher or letter in this Booke, Follovvinge herein the tyme and Å¿eaÅ¿on of the yeare. FirÅ¿t begininge vvith thoÅ¿e flovvers vvch are preÅ¿ented vnto vs in the Å¿pringe tyme, in regard that by the ConÅ¿ent of all vvryters, it is placed as the begininge of the yeare, even as Nature it Å¿elffe teacheth vs the Å¿ame. For the Earth beinge burthened, then Laboureth and trauaileth daily to be deliuered of that Burthen of her marvailouÅ¿e and admirable fruites, the vvch for a longe tyme had bene Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed by the violence of the vvynters colde. Thereby addinge the greater delight to the vnderÅ¿tandinge & occuler aÅ¿pection, by that vvonderfull and maruailous alteration and multiplicities of varieties, vvch therein may be obÅ¿erved. Intreatinge both the CourteouÅ¿e readers and alÅ¿o the diligent practiÅ¿ioners acceptably to receaue and entertaine theÅ¿e my laboures, and profitably to make vÅ¿e of them.

div.head: 1. The dubble blew Hepatica: or noble Liuerwort.
div.p: THe dubble blew Hepatica, hath a flower of many leaues verie Conveniently compoÅ¿ed together, being of a very Å¿ad blew tendinge towardes purple, and may be painted with a very high AÅ¿hcoloure, or elÅ¿e with a faire blew Azure mingled with a little lack in gomme water, in Å¿uch Å¿orte that the naturall gloÅ¿Å¿e may Å¿eeme to appeare, it may well be Å¿hadowed with indigo. The leaffe and Å¿teale there of may beÅ¿t be coloured with AÅ¿chcoloure and Å¿ad yellow wel mingled together, and Å¿hadowed wth the Å¿ame beinge made Å¿omewhat more Å¿adder, the Å¿teale may be rounded with Lack, the roote is of the coloure of maideÌ haire coloure, and may be beÅ¿t repreÅ¿ented with red and omber mingled.

div.head: The Å¿ingle Hepatica, or vvhyte Livervvort.
div.p: The flower of the whyte Hepatica is white as Å¿nowe, and the little Å¿eedes there of are yellowiÅ¿h yet tendinge to a pale red, the little heades thereof are greeniÅ¿h with Å¿ome little white Å¿tipples, and may be coloured wth pure whyte coloure and shadowed with florey.

div.head: 2. Lenten Saffron with Å¿male purple flowers.
div.p: THe flower of the Å¿male Lenten Saffron is almoÅ¿t of the Coloure of the purple violett, yet Å¿omewhat paler aboue, and Coloured by the Å¿teale of a Å¿adder purple, the three threedes of Saffron wch Å¿tand vpon the Å¿eed bole, are of a very faire yellow, and may be Å¿hadowed & Iagged with menie, the Å¿teale is white vpon red, and may be Å¿hadowed with aÅ¿hcoloure & maÅ¿ticott well mingled together. The sheathes or Codds where the flowers Å¿pringe out & bud are alÅ¿o of a ruddy, or a reddiÅ¿h coloure, and may be painted with a Å¿ad yellow, and Å¿hadowed with a little omber, the leaues are Å¿male & of a graÅ¿Å¿e greene, and may beÅ¿t be repreÅ¿ented in coloures with Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿hcoloure mingled to gether and furrowed or channeld downe with a white line or Å¿trake through the middle.

div.head: The flovver of the naples Saffron.
div.p: This is greater, yet in faÅ¿hion like vnto the former, not differinge in the coloure, havinge his Å¿eedebole of a golde yellow wth white furrowes in the middle, garniÅ¿hed with little knobs, at the end of a bright yellow coloure, turninge vp at the end, and Å¿melling very pleaÅ¿antly.

div.head: 3. The dubble NarciÅ¿Å¿us, or dubble yellow Daffodile.
div.p: THis flower is very thick of leaues, in regard where of it wanteth that Stockett wch Å¿ome other flowers have in the middle, the leaues thereof may be Coloured with maÅ¿ticott, and may be Å¿hadowed with oker or a darke yellow, the Å¿teale with verdegreece, and Å¿hadowed with Sap-greene, and the leaffe in like manner minglinge the verdegreece with a littel berry-greene both together.

div.head: The Daffodill vvith the triple Å¿ockett.
div.p: This flower is of a very faire golde yellow Coloure.

div.head: 4. The greate dubble NarciÅ¿Å¿us of porrett.
div.p: THe leaues of this flower are of a very pale yellow, and may be painted with light maÅ¿ticott, a little white beinge mingled vnder the Å¿ame, but the middle Å¿ockett, is of a faire golde yellow, and may be Å¿hadowed with omber.

div.head: The greateÅ¿t NaciÅ¿Å¿us vvith the dubble leaues.
div.p: This flower is of the Å¿ame Coloure as the former is, and differinge onely in the pluralitie of the leaues.

div.head: 5. The pleaÅ¿ant muÅ¿cari, or the yellow grape-flower.
div.p: THe flower of this muÅ¿cari is exceedingly Commended becauÅ¿e of his pleaÅ¿ant Å¿mell, and is of a perfect yellow Coloure, and therefore may be painted with faire berry yellow, beinge illuÅ¿trated with faire light maÅ¿ticot, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿ad yellow beinge mingled with a little lack and greene together, the Å¿tipples are blewiÅ¿h of indigo and white mingled together, the Å¿teale may be painted with mountaine greene and white together Å¿o farre as the flowers hange downewardes, but lower with verdegreece, beinge Å¿princkled all over with Å¿male Å¿potts of purple and lack mingled together, the leaffe may be painted with mountaine greene, and Å¿hadowed with verdegreece.

div.head: The vvhyte muÅ¿cari, or the vvhite grape-flovver.
div.p: This flower is onely differinge in Coloure beinge of a more vnpleaÅ¿anter, Å¿ullied, or Å¿adder white.

div.head: 6. The Radiall Iacynth of Guienne.
div.p: THe flower of this Iacynth is of a blewiÅ¿h purple and may be Coloured with lack and aÅ¿hcoloure with a little white beinge mingled there vnder, the Å¿eedes there of Coloured with indigo and lack as likewiÅ¿e the Å¿male Å¿cutchion wch Å¿tandeth in the middle thereÃ²f, the Å¿male braunches whervpon thoÅ¿e flowers doe Å¿tand are Å¿omwhat blewiÅ¿h, the Å¿teale below may be painted with Å¿paniÅ¿h greene and maÅ¿ticot together, the tops thereof with a little white and verdegreece together, and Å¿hadowed wth Å¿apgreene, thoÅ¿e thinne Å¿kinns at the end of the flowers are greene and Å¿hadowed with indigo.

div.head: The Radiall SpaniÅ¿h Iacynth.
div.p: The flower of this Radiall Iacynth, & the leaues of the Å¿paniÅ¿h Lillies both in forme and faÅ¿hion doe agree with the former, the leaues beinge fully as longe, and are of a very pure whyte Coloure.

div.head: 7. The EngliÅ¿h dubble prime roÅ¿e.
div.p: THe flower of this primula veris (Å¿o called in Lattine) in this Å¿eaÅ¿on doe appeare, they are of a yellow Coloure, and may be painted with faire maÅ¿ticot yellow, beinge topt with light maÅ¿ticot, and Å¿hadowed with Saffron or a Å¿ad yellow. The Å¿eedeboles are of the coloure of mountaine greene, the Å¿talke is whitiÅ¿h and may be Å¿hadowed with mountaine greene & Å¿ad yellow tempered together. The leafe is of a light greene Å¿omwhat yellowiÅ¿hâª & may be painted with mountaine greene mingled wth a little maÅ¿ticott, the furrowes of the leaues may be painted with Å¿ad aÅ¿hcoloure Å¿ad yellow and a little Å¿apgreene all mingled together, or elÅ¿e alone with Å¿apgreene, the pointes or the height of the leaues with a little whyte and Å¿ad yellow tempered together, and about the very end of the leaffe, the R â¢ bbes may be repreÅ¿ented with lack Coloure, as alÅ¿o the Å¿teales of the leaues are towardes theire endes Å¿omwhat reddiÅ¿h.

div.head: The dubble CovvÅ¿lipp.
div.p: The other twiÅ¿e dubble flower is in forme and faÅ¿hion much differinge froÌ the former, as conÅ¿iÅ¿tinge of tvvo perfect Å¿ingle flowers, the one cominge out of the middle of the other, yet in Coloure like vnto the former.

div.head: 8. Auricula vrÅ¿i, or yellow Beares-eares.
div.p: THe flower of this firÅ¿t Beares-eare is perfect Å¿traw-Coloure, or brimÅ¿tone Coloure, havinge in the middle within it, a whyte ringe, from whence there ariÅ¿eth out of a little rounde hollow Å¿ome few Å¿male Å¿priggs Coloured yellow about that rounde, the Sockett of this flower is of a pale yellow Å¿omwhat greeniÅ¿h, and may be painted with light maÅ¿ticott and aÅ¿h-Coloure, the Å¿teale downewardes is of a pale greene, and as it were Å¿princkled over with meale. The leaffe thereof is very like the leaffe of the primeroÅ¿e, but Å¿mooth without any veines, appearinge alÅ¿o Å¿omwhat whyte as if they were Å¿trewed over with meale.

div.head: The violl at Coloured beares-eare.
div.p: The forme and faÅ¿hion of this flower is almoÅ¿t agreeinge with the former, but Å¿omewhat greater, of a faire Violet Coloure, havinge in the middle thereof a cercuite of a pale yellowiÅ¿h Coloure, and in the middle of that a Å¿male rounde, of a Å¿adder violett Coloure, and may be painted with lack and a little indigo mingled therewith.

div.head: 9. The flagg-flower deluce, with broade leaves.
div.p: THeÅ¿e are here repreÅ¿ented in two Å¿euerall Å¿ortes, the firÅ¿t hath flowers of a blew violett Coloure beinge Å¿tript throughout with a Å¿adder blew theÌ the flower is, and is Å¿hadowed alÅ¿o in the Å¿ame faÅ¿hion, but topt Å¿omwhat lighter. The leaff agreeth almoÅ¿t with the leaues of the comone flower de luce. The other Å¿orte of theÅ¿e flower deluces are of a more Å¿adder purple, eÅ¿petially in the three nethermoÅ¿t depeÌdinge leaves, wch Å¿eeme Å¿omewhat roughe, as Å¿ad purple velvett, havinge from bellow vnto the middle ryÅ¿inge vp a hayrie fringe, like vnto faire yellow Å¿ilke, the leaves that Å¿tand vpright are of a pleaÅ¿anter Coloure.

div.head: 10. The Orientall Iacynth.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t Orientall Iacynth, hath his flowers of a purple blewiÅ¿h Coloure, beinge topt with a little whyte and blew, and Å¿hadowed with indigo and lack mingled together, within they Å¿eeme to be a little whyter, and toward the knopes Å¿omewhat more purple, the Å¿teales where vpon the flowers doe depend are of a tomone greene, and the great Å¿teale may be painted with verdigreece, beinge there with all topt and Å¿hadowed as is moÅ¿t convenient for theÌ, yet the little Å¿ports at the ryÅ¿inge out of the Å¿teale is almoÅ¿t whyte. The Bole is of AÅ¿h-coloure mingled with a little omber, and Å¿hadowed with lack and indigo mingled, a little whyte added thereunto Å¿erues for the toppinge of it. The leaffe may be painted with Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿h-Coloure, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene, and for the toppinge of them take mountaine greene mingled with a little whyte.

div.head: The other Orientall Iacynth.
div.p: This other hath his flowers Å¿omewhat greater, and is of a more paler purple Coloure, yet otherwiÅ¿e very like vnto the former.

div.head: 11. The Orientall Iacynth with the leaved Å¿talke.
div.p: THis Iacynth with the leaved Å¿talke, hath his flowers very like in Coloure to the former, but the longe leaues vpon the Å¿talke muÅ¿t be painted with Å¿apgreene.

div.head: The dubble orientall Iacynth.
div.p: But this dubble orieÌtall Iacynth hath at his firÅ¿t cominge greene flowers, wch afterwardes appeare Å¿omwhat blewiÅ¿h, and beinge full blowne, are whyte yet Å¿omewhat greeniÅ¿h, yet thoÅ¿e, Å¿tripes or veines that goe through the leaues are very greene.

div.head: 12. The Imperiall Crowne.
div.p: THe dependinge flowers of the Imperiall Crowne may be painted with oker and a little meny mingled together, and the rares thereof, with lack and Å¿ad yellow mingled together, yet for the expreÅ¿Å¿inge of the browneÅ¿Å¿e at the endes of the leaves take a little indigo amonge the former, the clappers that hange within with the knopps, Coloure them with a pale yellow mingled with a little oker, and may be topt Å¿omewhat bright, and Å¿hadovved vvith lack, the Å¿teale may be both topt and Å¿hadovved very conveniently vvith verdegreece.

div.head: 13. The comon purple Anemone: or wynde flower.
div.p: THeÅ¿e three Å¿everall Å¿ortes of wynde flowers, with the Å¿male leaues are of all other flowers moÅ¿t differinge in Coloure from each other. The firÅ¿t flower of them is of a faire violett Coloure, topt with light azure, the Å¿eed boles are Å¿ad purple, the budds are of indigo coloure.

div.head: The Scarlett Coloured Anemone: or vvynde flovver.
div.p: The Å¿econd Å¿orte of them is of a perfect Scarlet Coloure, and may be painted with vermilion, and topt with lack and white both mingled together, the grounde of them is of a Å¿ilver Coloure Å¿tript with Å¿male crimÅ¿on coloured veines, the budds are of a blew purple, thiere little Å¿teale is bloode red, and the middelmoÅ¿t bole is of a Å¿ad purple almoÅ¿t black, and is topt with a RuÅ¿Å¿et Coloure. TheÅ¿e (as alÅ¿o all the wynde flowers comonly) in Colouringe them muÅ¿t be very well gomde and varniÅ¿ht for the better demonÅ¿tratinge of the glance and Å¿hyninge brightneÅ¿Å¿e thereof. The Å¿talke is greene vpon red vp to the very flower, but belowe is more greeniÅ¿h painted with mountane greene, and may be Å¿hadowed with aÅ¿h-coloure and Å¿ad yellow mingled, and topt with whyte and maÅ¿ticote.

div.head: The princely vvynde flovver: or Anemone.
div.p: The thirde Å¿orte of theÅ¿e flowers, by reaÅ¿on of theire exceedinge beauty are called the princely wynde flower, and may be painted with vermilion and lack tempered together, the grounde thereof is Å¿omewhat lighter with Å¿preadinge raies throughout even vnto the Å¿eedes (wch are of Azure blew) and a little whyter, the Å¿eedbole is of the coloure of indigo Å¿hadowed with a little Lambe black the coloure of the Å¿teale is as verdigieece & a little maÅ¿ticott amonge the Å¿ame. The leafe may bepointed with mountaine greene and verdigreece together, and Å¿hadowed with aÅ¿hcoloure & Å¿ad yellovv mingled together wch a little Å¿apgreene, but towardes the Å¿teale it is alwaies of a lighter coloure Å¿omevvhat towardes yellow, and topt wth mountaine greene.

div.head: 14. The wynde Flower of a Å¿male leafe, or the Å¿male-leafed-wyndeflower being dubble and of a maydens bluÅ¿h.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿ortes of wyndeflovvers beinge very dubble and vvith Å¿male leaues, are in forme very little differinge from each other, yet the former of them is of a maydens bluÅ¿h, but at the bottome of the leaues a Å¿adder red, and may be topt with whyte and blevv, and may be Å¿hadovved with lack and blew both beinge mingled together.

div.head: The CrimÅ¿on coloured vvynde flovver.
div.p: But the other of theÅ¿e dubble flowers is of a faire CrimÅ¿on coloure, and may be painted with faire vermilion, Å¿hadowed with lack, and topt with lack, and white mingled together.

div.head: 15. The broade leafde wynde Flower.
div.p: THeÅ¿e three followinge wynde flowers, are very much differinge both in theire leaues, coloure, and faÅ¿hion. The firÅ¿t of them is of a faire vermillion & a little lack tempered the â¢â¢ vnder with an appearance of a purple couloure Å¿hyninge or glancinge vpon it, the grounde beinge whyte, vvith exceedinge Å¿male veines of a yellow coloure, the Å¿eede bol â¢â¢ s black, the threedes or Å¿eedes are of the coloure of Indigo tempered with a little vvhyte, the Å¿teale is garniÅ¿hed vvith Å¿tripes of white omber, or a Å¿ad yellow beinge tempered vvth a little lack. The leafe is coloured vvith mountaine greene and Å¿hadowed vvith verdegreece.

div.head: The Å¿paniÅ¿h vvynde flovver.
div.p: The Å¿econde Å¿orte is of an carnation coloure like vnto the roÅ¿es of provance, the grounde of the leaues is of vvhitiÅ¿h yellow, the little knopes are of a Å¿ad blew, and the m â¢ delmoÅ¿t bole is yet more Å¿adder.

div.head: The Oringe Coloured vvyndeflovver.
div.p: The thirde Å¿orte of theÅ¿e flowers is of a perfect Oringe tawney coloure, and may be painted with faire vermillion and maÅ¿ticott appearing in the ground thereof, Å¿hadovved with lack, and with the veines which Å¿hoote through the leaues may be dravvne, the little knopes of an Azure blevv, and may be Å¿hadovved vvith Indigo, and topt vvith vvhyte.

div.head: 16. The Å¿ingle peacocks wyndeflower.
div.p: THeÅ¿e tvvo Å¿ortes of broade leafde vvyndeflovvers, are comonly called by the name of peacocks. And the firÅ¿t of them is Å¿ingle leafde, and of a faire red couloure.

div.head: The dubble peacocks vvyndeflovvers.
div.p: The other dubble vvynde flower is of a faire Å¿carlet coloure, and may be painted with pure vermillion, being topt with lack & a little white, and Å¿hadowed onely with lack, the grounde which compaÅ¿Å¿eth the middle-crowne is a light maÅ¿ticot yellow, the knopes muÅ¿t be of a willow greene, and the middle bole bloode red Å¿omwhat tendinge towarde a murrey, the Å¿teale with mountaine greene, but yet aboue to wardes the flower Å¿omewhat reddiÅ¿h, and the middle leafe Å¿tript through with a whyte veine, the leaues are coloured with mountaine greene, ad Å¿hadowed with verdigreece and aÅ¿hcoloure.

div.head: 17. The Chalcedonian wyndeflowers.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two very faire dubble wynde flowers are very rare, and called by the name of Chalcedonian & very delectable to beholde, the firÅ¿t of them is of a faire bigneÅ¿Å¿e adorned with many leaues, where of 8 or 10. of the outtermoÅ¿t are greene, beÅ¿ett with veines of a vermilion coloure, the other leaues are Å¿maler and of a faire vermilion coloure mingled with meny, and endinge with Å¿ome prettie white flames as braunches, havinge in the middle certaine curled leaues in the place of the Å¿eedbole, coveringe the heades wch are of a pale yellow and meny, and yet Å¿omevvhat lighter at the bottome.

div.head: The other Chalcedonian vvyndeflovver.
div.p: The other flovver of theÅ¿e tvvo, is Å¿omewhat leÅ¿Å¿er yet very dubble being at the grounde Å¿omevvhat vvhytiÅ¿h, the leaues flaminge vvith lack, whyte and vermilion coloures one throughe another, the innermoÅ¿t Å¿eedes are of light maÅ¿ticot, the Å¿teale is light mountaine greene, the leaues are mountaine greene, Å¿hadowed with verdigreece, the outtermoÅ¿t Å¿ide is of a Å¿adder coloure.

div.head: 18. Adonis flower: or Eranthemum.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e comonly called Adonis flovver, is of a faire bloode red coloure, and may be coloured vvith lack and vermilion mingled together, and Å¿hadowed onely vvith lack, the bole is of a decaied lack red, or as it vvere withered, being topt with lack and white, the Å¿eedes are of Indigo coloure mingled with a little oker, the Å¿teale is mountaine greene mingled vvith maÅ¿ticot, and Å¿o is the leafe alÅ¿o but Å¿omewhat more greeniÅ¿h and is Å¿hadowed with Å¿ad yellow, aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿apgreene al mingled together.
The other of theÅ¿e comonly called the cowe eie is yellow and garniÅ¿hed in the midle with Å¿priggs of a reddiÅ¿h Å¿affron coloure.

div.head: 19. NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower, or the Oxe eie.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿ortes of the Å¿male leafd' NarciÅ¿Å¿us, are in coloures of theire flowers very different, the firÅ¿t flower conÅ¿iÅ¿tinge of Å¿ix white leaues havinge a longe hoÅ¿e or challice that extendes it Å¿elffe far out, garniÅ¿hed about with a red border, the middle knopes are withered yellow and Å¿ometymes Å¿omewhat reddiÅ¿h, the Å¿teale is mountaine greene, the leafers mountaine greene mingled with aÅ¿hcoloure. The Å¿hadowe is of verdigreece and Å¿apgreene, and topt with a little white amonge the Å¿ame. The Å¿kin or huÅ¿ke from out of wch the flower proceedeth is of a ruÅ¿Å¿ett coloure, Å¿hadowed vvith aÅ¿hcoloure and mingled inflames with omber. The other NarciÅ¿Å¿us hath a very yellovv Å¿ockett, with a Å¿affroÌ coloured border about the edge, very curled, and may be painted with pale oker, and Å¿omewhat greeniÅ¿h with in, the little wattels are brimÅ¿tone coloure, the white leaues may be coloured with white leade and a little bright maÅ¿ticot mingled, & Å¿hadowed with Lambs-black.

div.head: 20. NarciÅ¿Å¿us Flower with the longe Sockett.
div.p: HEre are Å¿hewed two Å¿ortes of broade leafd' NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers, whereof the firÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿tes of Å¿ix white leaues as the former flowers doe, but the Å¿ockett is very longe and greater, of a faire yellow coloure, havinge Å¿ix Å¿priggs of a pale yellow about the bole of it where vpon hange the knopes beinge of a darker yellow.

div.head: The other NarciÅ¿Å¿us flovver.
div.p: The other NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower differeth but a very little from the former, but that oftentymes there comes two flowers out of one Å¿teale.

div.head: 21. The white NarciÅ¿Å¿us Flower.
div.p:
THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers are little, Snow-whyte, with a pure white Sockett, havinge in the midÅ¿t three or foure knopes of a light
yellow, and are Å¿hadowed with mally or lampe black, the Å¿teales of the flowers are of a Å¿ad greene, the lower Å¿teale is mountaine greene and Å¿hadowed with verdigreece, and the leaves may be Coloured with the Å¿ome.

div.head: The dubble narciÅ¿Å¿us flovver.
div.p: The other narciÅ¿Å¿us flower is greate and faire, and the leaves are very vvhite, havinge in the place of the Sockett Å¿ix other white leaves, Å¿maler then the other, where there runneth veines of yellow through the Å¿ame.

div.head: 22. The greateÅ¿t NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower.
div.p: THis firÅ¿t narciÅ¿Å¿us flower is very faire and the greateÅ¿t, havinge ruÅ¿Å¿et leaves, Å¿omewhat like vnto the whiteÅ¿t brimÅ¿tone, the Sockett is of yellow oker mingled with maÅ¿ticot, Å¿hadowed with omber, and topt with faire maÅ¿ticott, the border thereof reÅ¿emblinge a faded red Coloure. The leafe and Å¿teale may be Coloured with mountaine greene, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿paniÅ¿h greene accordinge as is requiÅ¿ite.

div.head: The Italian narciÅ¿Å¿us flovver.
div.p: The other Italian narciÅ¿Å¿us flower is faire and greate, and of a pale brimÅ¿tone Coloure or a honey yellow, havinge a Sockett of a golde yellow Coloure.

div.head: 23. The yellow RuÅ¿hie NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers according to his proportion hath a great Socket of golde yellow coloure, the leaues are yellow, and likewiÅ¿e alÅ¿o the knopes hanging vpon the yellowiÅ¿h Å¿priggs, and yet every yellow is a little different from another.

div.head: The vvhite RuÅ¿hie NarciÅ¿Å¿us.
div.p: The other RuÅ¿hie or rather Reedelijke leaued NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower, is of a perfect white coloure havinge Å¿ome leaues curled or turned vp like vnto the faÅ¿hion of the flower caled Cyclamen or Å¿ow-breade, with a longe Sockett Å¿tandinge out, (within the which are three white Å¿priggs with Å¿affron coloured knopes at theire endes,) which compaÅ¿Å¿eth the feedebole.

div.head: 24. The thick RuÅ¿hie NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers which are Å¿et downe here, is full of leaues, without either Å¿ocket or Å¿eedebole, being of a faire golde yellow coloure, and Å¿hadowed with omber and browne maÅ¿ticort.

div.head: The NarciÅ¿Å¿us flovver vvith the great Å¿ocket.
div.p: The other of theÅ¿e is Å¿ingle leaued, and of a yellow coloure and may be painted with maÅ¿ticort, and Å¿hadowed therewith in like manner, theÅ¿e are of the greateÅ¿t Å¿orte, with Reedie leaues, havinge in the middle of them a greate Å¿ockett which farre Å¿tretcheth out it Å¿elffe, of a yellowiÅ¿h Å¿affron coloure.

div.head: 25. The PerÅ¿ian Lilley.
div.p: THe PerÅ¿ian Lilley bringes forth many flowers of fiue of Å¿ix leaues a peece, hanginge downewardes like bells, theire coloure is of a vvithered or Å¿tayned purple coloure, like vnto the coloure of the reÅ¿inges of the Å¿onne, and may be painted with Indigo and lack vvith a little Å¿mair mingled together, and may be Å¿hadowed with the Å¿ame coloure, and may be topt at the very ende with white, a little blew and lack, being all mingled together.

div.head: 26. The tymely flowringe Tulipa.
div.p: THeÅ¿e three tymely or earlie Tulips which are here repreÅ¿ented are painted as followeth. The firÅ¿t flower hath leaues of a pale purple coloure, mingled with aÅ¿hcoloure, lack and whyte: Å¿hadowed with lack and topt with white: the leaffe is mountaine greene, Å¿hadovved vvith Å¿apgreene and topt vvith mountaine greene mingled with a little white.

div.head: The vvhite flovver'd tymely Tulipa.
div.p: The Seconde is pale and Å¿omwhat yellovviÅ¿h topt vvith pure vvhite, and Å¿hadovved vvith a very darck greene.

div.head: VVolfsvvinckel Tulipa.
div.p: The thirde Å¿orte of theÅ¿e is of a purple Coloure, vvith vvhite borders, and may be Å¿hadovved vvith lack Coloure, as moÅ¿t agreeing vnto the Å¿ame Coloure, and topt vvith vvhite.

div.head: 27. The perÅ¿ian Tulipa.
div.p: THe perÅ¿ian Tulipa hath Å¿ix leaues Å¿tanding vpright, the one of a bright purple, and the other very vvhite: the vvhite leaues may be Å¿hadovved vvith black and blevv, and purple and lack Coloure, and the borders may be topt vvith a little white beinge mingled there vvith, the middle Å¿eede bole is greene, and the Å¿priggs that Å¿tand about it are blacke.

div.head: The Candian Tulipa.
div.p: The other Candian Tulip is a flovver of purple Coloure mingled vvith vvhite Å¿trypes, Å¿hadovved vvith lack and topt vvith vvhite in the middle there of both aÅ¿vvel vvith in as vvithout, beneath it is Å¿princkled vvith menny, the knopes vvithin are of the glance of a very Å¿ad purple.

div.head: 28. Tulipa pumilus, or little Tulipa.
div.p: THe little Tulipa flovver is Coloured with menny topt with maÅ¿ticot or yellovv oker, and Å¿hadovved vvith lack.

div.head: Tulipa BononienÅ¿is.
div.p: The Tulipa of Bonnonia is of the Coloure of maÅ¿ticot, Å¿hadovved vvith Å¿ad aker, and the middle Å¿trype that is in the leafe is of verdegreece as alÅ¿o the Å¿eedes, the knopes or budds that Å¿tand Å¿o far out are Å¿hadovved vvith menny.

div.head: 29. Tulipa ducis.
div.p: HEre are preÅ¿ented three Å¿ortes of Tulip flowers, the firÅ¿t is like vnto cloth of golde, and may be painted with faire yellow, topt with maÅ¿ticot and Å¿hadowed with lack, the roote is of a pale Å¿oet colour, topt with white, and Å¿hadowed with browne.
The other is of a Å¿traw coloure, topt with a little white, and Å¿hadowed with a little black.

div.head: Tulipa alba.
div.p: The thirde Å¿orte of theÅ¿e is like vnto a white roÅ¿e, of lack and white mingled together, the topping and borderinge of the Å¿ame is Å¿traw coloure, the lower moÅ¿t parte towardes the Å¿teale is white, and Å¿hadowed throughout with lack, yet the middle ribbe of the leaffe is perfect yellow.

div.head: 30. Tulipa Å¿anguina.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e flowers is bloode-red, and may be painted with lack and vermillion mingled together, and Å¿hadowed with a Å¿adder lack, and topt with vermillion and a little menny, theÅ¿e coloures may be wel gommed the better to Å¿hew the glance of the leaues.

div.head: Tulipa Cinna:
div.p: The other flower is white, flamed throughout with menny and vermilion, Å¿hadowed with a little lack, and is below towardes the Å¿teale Å¿omewhat greeniÅ¿h out of a white.

div.head: 31. Tulipa HonneÅ¿ti.
div.p: THeÅ¿e three Tulip flowers are very faire and delectable, the firÅ¿t is very great and beÅ¿t knowne by the name honeÅ¿ti, beinge very cunningly Å¿potted interlaced and flamed with lack and white the one amonge the other, and betweene them here and there Å¿ome greater Å¿tripps and flames of lack, beinge below at the bottom of the leafe Å¿omwhat yellowiÅ¿h, and now and then Å¿ome appearances of yellow coloure.

div.head: Tulipa Nivea.
div.p: The Å¿econde is a Å¿maler flower, of a white coloure, and in the middle of the leafe hath a faire Å¿trype of lack, and garniÅ¿hed about the edge with pretty little flames of the Å¿ame coloure.

div.head: Tulipa alba:
div.p: The thirde Å¿orte of theÅ¿e is alÅ¿o white, with Å¿omwhat broder Å¿trypes and flames cleane throughout of lack coloure.

div.head: 32. Tulipa alba cum rubris flam:
div.p: THeÅ¿e two which are here placed, are not inferior to any of the former, the firÅ¿t is white mingled with brimÅ¿tone coloure, flamed throughout with lack, Å¿omewhat paler below, & aboue of a Scarlet red, the glance is given by a thinne white Å¿troke vpon it.
The other hath aÅ¿much yellow vnder the white, and his Å¿trippes and flames are of a nother manner, like as the picture of the flower and the Å¿hadowinge thereof very lively expreÅ¿Å¿eth.

div.head: 33. Checkered daffodills, & white.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿ortes of Checkered daffodills have different coloured flowers: the firÅ¿t flower is milke white, but a little towardes the Å¿teale is a little greeniÅ¿h, Å¿omthinge one of a yellow, the Ribbes which goe about this flower are greeniÅ¿h, the Å¿teale and the leaues may be painted with aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿ad yellow tempered together the toppinge of mountaine greene and white together, the Å¿hadowe neereÅ¿t vnto the lack coloure, the Å¿eedebole and thee Å¿eedes are white with yellow knopes.

The other of theÅ¿e two is whitiÅ¿h, but the vppermoÅ¿t edges and parte of the flower is Checkered with red Å¿potts of lack, the Ribbes that Å¿well out are of a Å¿adder red, and greene about the Å¿teale.

div.head: 34. Other Checkered daffodills.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿ortes are greater then the preceedinge flowers are. The firÅ¿t hath his leaues of a golde yellow very finely garniÅ¿hed with Å¿potts of bloode red, and a greeniÅ¿h Ribbe goeinge through every leafe.
The other being the greateÅ¿t is Å¿peckled with the like coulored Å¿potts, but more thicker, yet tendinge towardes a purple coloure.

div.head: 35. Orinthogalum, or the Å¿tarre of Bethlehem.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿taire flovvers here expreÅ¿Å¿ed, are onely differinge in bigneÅ¿Å¿e from another, the flovvers are vvhite, and the little knopes (vpon the Å¿priggs that are vvhite,) are maÅ¿ticot yellovv, the leaues thereof vpon the outÅ¿ide haue a greeniÅ¿h circle of a graÅ¿Å¿e greene coloure Å¿omevvhat broade, all tending tovvardes greene, the Å¿teales are mounta ne greene broken vvith vvhite, Å¿hadovved vvith ve â¢ digreece, the little leaues that hang onder the Å¿teale are vvhitiÅ¿h, havinge an ere of greene vpon theire right Å¿ides, and may be Å¿hadovved vvith lambe black, the leafe is of a graÅ¿Å¿e greene tempered vvith maÅ¿ticot, vvhite, and Å¿add yellovv, to his proportion.

div.head: 36. The great white AÅ¿phodill flower.
div.p: HEre are repreÅ¿ented two Å¿ortes of AÅ¿phodill flowers, the firÅ¿t hath leaues of the coloure of Å¿opps in wyne, the Å¿trippe that goeth through them, and the hindmoÅ¿t knopes are of oker and lack together, the knopes and Å¿eedes are of a Å¿ad oker coloure, the Å¿talke is mountaine greene Å¿hadowed with verdigreece, the little Å¿ide Å¿teales are mountaine greene and Å¿ad oker mingled, the little leaues vpon them are of Å¿ad oker and lack, topt with white. The leafe is like vnto the Å¿talke, of a mountaine greene, Å¿hadowed with verdigreece.

div.head: The yellovv AÅ¿phodill flovver.
div.p: This other is very like vnto the former, but of a yellow coloure, & the leafe is Å¿omwhat blewiÅ¿h.

div.head: 37. Columbines.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e his called after is proportion the RoÅ¿e columbine, is of a a Å¿ad purple coloure, and may be painted with browne blew and lack and red mingled together, taking very little browne blew there vnto, leÅ¿Å¿e it Å¿houlde be too Å¿ad, and darken the purple as much as may be. The head in the middle is of a light greene, and the knopes about it are whitiÅ¿h the vpper parte of the Å¿teale is Å¿omewhat like vnto purple.

div.head: The Starrey Columbines.
div.p: The Coloure of the Starrey Columbines are alÅ¿o of a Å¿ad purple and may be painted vvith Indigo & lack, and minglinge a little white vnder it even to the middle of the leafe, and Å¿o towardes the end of it a more paler blevv, the Å¿eed codds are greeniÅ¿h topt with maÅ¿ticot, the knopes or budds are white, the Å¿teale is of a pleaÅ¿ant greene of verdigreece and white mingled together, the leaffe is blewiÅ¿h of mountaine greene and verdigreece mingled together, Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene, and the edges topt with greene and white.

div.head: 38. Crowes-feete or Bachelers buttons.
div.p:
THeÅ¿e two Å¿ortes of Crowes-feete flowers are very different from each other. The firÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿tinge of Å¿ingle leaues after the manner of the Anemone or wynde-flower, of a faire red coloure, and hath in the middle a round Å¿eedebole, the kernells that Å¿tande about the Å¿ame may be p â¢â¢ nted
with Å¿ad yellow; and Å¿hadowed with omber, and the middlemoÅ¿t knopes being of a Å¿ad purple are of lack and indigo mingled together, the leaffe is mountaine greene, Å¿hadowed with Å¿ap-greene, and the Å¿teales alÅ¿o, that parte where the flower hangeth vpon may be painted with white, red, and greene tempered altogether.

div.head: 39. White Crowes-feete flowers.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e Crowes-feete flowers, hath a whyte flower and very dubble in leaues, wherein appeares certaine Å¿traines of a pale greene, the vppermoÅ¿t edges are Å¿omewhat reddiÅ¿h.

div.head: The great round Crovves-feete.
div.p: The other hath a great flower, the leaues alwaies bendinge inwarde, being of a faire yellow coloure, and may be Å¿hadowed with Å¿ad yellow and a little vermilion mingled, & topt aboue with bright maÅ¿ticot, the knopes or budds that looke out from with in, are maÅ¿ticot yellow, the leafe is of a Å¿ad greene, topt with omber, and aÅ¿hcoloure, and a little white together, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene, the Å¿teale is Å¿omwhat brighter, and may be topt with maÅ¿ticot.

div.head: 40. Satyrion, or male foole-Å¿tones, or hare-Å¿toons.
div.p: THe male Satyrion hath flowers like vnto friars hoodes being white, but the covers have Å¿tripes of a greeniÅ¿h purple Å¿carce appearinge, the Å¿teales and the leaues whereon the flowers doe hange, are of a pale verdigreece and white mingled together, the leaffe is alÅ¿o verdigreece and white together, and a little maÅ¿ticot amonge the Å¿ame, and may be Å¿hadowed vvith, verdigreece, and vpon the leaffe may be marked a kynde of Å¿male Å¿potts glanc â¢ nge throughout the Å¿ame.

div.head: The female Satyrion.
div.p: The flower of the female Satyrion which is here firÅ¿t placed, is like vnto a pale roÅ¿e coloure, Å¿hadowed with lack and indigo, and topt with white and lack together, the Å¿potts and threedes are of a Å¿ad purple red, the little Å¿teales are of the berrie yellow, laced with verdigreece, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene, the Å¿male leaue, betwixt the flowers are of a greeniÅ¿h purple, the lower Å¿teale is mountaine greene Å¿princled with white, the leaues may be coloured with maÅ¿ticot and mountaine greene; the covers, with verdigreece and Å¿apgreene mingled together, and the toppinge of it with maÅ¿ticot, the flackes or Å¿ports are black vpon greene.

div.head: 41. The RuÅ¿hie NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower.
div.p: THeÅ¿e 2. Å¿ortes of RuÅ¿hie NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers, differ nothinge but in the greatneÅ¿Å¿e from each other, And called by the Å¿paniards Ioncquilles, Å¿omewhat Å¿maler theÌ the comoÌ NarciÅ¿Å¿us or oxe-eie, & is of a faire yellow coloure, Å¿hadovved vvith omber and Å¿ad maÅ¿ticot, the Sockett is more yellovver, vvherein grovveth three or foure Å¿male Å¿p â¢ iggs, the Å¿teale is yellovviÅ¿h even to the knope, but aftervvardes it is of Å¿apgreene and verdigreece mingled together, Å¿hadovved vvith omber, the leaff is mountaine greene Å¿hadovved vvith verdigreece.

div.p: ET d'autant que les raÃ§ines des Tulipes peuvent eÅ¿tre endommagez par pluÅ¿ieurs & divers accidentz, qui tournent Å¿ouvent au grand deÅ¿plaiÅ¿ir & meÅ¿contentement de ceux quy les ayment & qui les poÅ¿Å¿edent, je les ay bien voullu advertir d'un, entre pluÅ¿ieurs acÃ§identz qui peuvent arriver a cela qui eÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ez dangereux, aÅ¿Å¿avoir, que les boulles ou raÃ§ines Å¿e trouvent Å¿ouventefois endommagez des vers ou lombris qui les font mourir. Ce qui je peult remedier en ceÅ¿te faÃ§on, quand elles Å¿eront levÃ©es hors de la terre, & quae l'on verra quil y aura quelque dommage des vers en icelles ou en aucunne, vous la mettrez au Å¿oleil avec du Å¿ablon a l'entour & les laiÅ¿Å¿erez ainÅ¿y par quelques jours ainÅ¿y elles Å¿eront garantyes.

div.p: POur garder ou retenir longuement les Tulipans en fleur, il les fault garder fort Å¿oingneuÅ¿ement & dilligement que la pluye ne tumbe deÅ¿Å¿us la nuict, & pour ce faire vous prendrez du parchemin & en ferez des petits capuchons de grandeur ptoppres pour â¢ ouvrir vos Tulipans, puis les ayant attachez a des petitz baÅ¿tons, vous les ficherez auprez de vos fleurs, de Å¿orte que le capuch â¢ n Å¿era droict pendant Å¿ur voÅ¿tre Tulipan pour le couvrir juÅ¿tement fa fleur qu'and il pleuvera Å¿oit de nuict ou de jour, ou quand le temps Å¿era pluvieux, ou quand il fera trop de froid, & cecy Ã¡ ceÅ¿tÃ© experimente de Å¿orte que l'on peult en ceÅ¿te faÃ§on conÅ¿ervir vn Tulipan en Å¿a plaine fleur bien Å¿ix ou Å¿ept Å¿epmaines, quy autrement ne dure pas plus longuement que 12. ou 14. jours.

div.head: 1. The female peionie flower.
div.p: THis greatÅ¿t female peionie flower, conÅ¿iÅ¿teth of very manie leaues and my be painted with lack and a little vermilion mingled with it, Å¿hadowed with glancinge browne lack, and topt with white and a little lack thereby. The leaffe may be coloured with aÅ¿hcoloure, m â¢â¢ ticot, and a little Å¿ad yellow all mingled together, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿apg â¢ ene. A little white added vnto the former coloures wil Å¿erue for the toppinge of it, the budde is of a faire red like vnto the flower, but Å¿omwhat Å¿adder, the pillinges thereof are as the leaffe of the flower, the Å¿teale is a pale â¢ teene, the toppinge thereof is Å¿ad yellow, and the Å¿hadowe is of verdig â¢ e â¢â¢

div.head: 2. Iris maior Dodonaei: or the field flower de luce.
div.p: THis great flower de luce expreÅ¿Å¿ed by Dodonaeus, hath his three n â¢ ther moÅ¿t dependinge leaues, beinge vnder pale and of a faire blew purple aboue reÅ¿emblinge the violet with white Å¿tripes takinge theire begininge from the golden fringe, ouer the vvhich are Å¿male pale purple coloured leaues hanginge, the three leaues that Å¿tand vpright are of a light purpleâª and are Å¿hadowed there vnto as is fittinge.

div.head: 3. The flower de luce of SuÅ¿a.
div.p: THe flower deluce of SuÅ¿a is a BrowniÅ¿h aÅ¿hcoloure, beinge full of blackiÅ¿h Å¿potts and veines, (as the picture well declareth, his leÅ¿Å¿er leaues which are in the middle haue a purple border through the middle of them. The leafe and the Å¿teale may be painted with mountaine greene and verdigreece, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿ap-greene with his Å¿tripes in â¢â¢â¢ e manner as is fittinge.

div.head: 4. The Narrow leafde flower deluce.
div.p: THis is alÅ¿o a very delicate flower deluce, & the leaues Å¿taÌding vpright may be painted with a Å¿ad blew aÅ¿hcoloure and lack mingled together, Å¿hadowed with Indigo and purple lack, the downe-warde bendinge leaues are Å¿tript with Å¿ad purple flames, and towards the edge is appearance of light aker & lack, the middle leaninge leaues beinge but Å¿male are a Å¿ad purple, the Å¿teale is verdigreece with mountaine greene, and a little berry yellow mingled together. The Å¿hort Å¿teale wherevpon the flowers doe growe is aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿ad yellow, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿ap-greene.

div.head: 5. SyÅ¿inrichium maius. or the BaÅ¿tard flower deluce.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e two here expreÅ¿Å¿ed flower deluces, is of a very pleaÅ¿ant coloure, havinge his extended leaues of an Azur blew and a little lack appearing â¢ nder the Å¿ame, the other Å¿tripps are lack and Indigo, the innermoÅ¿t leaues may be Å¿hadowed with lack and indigo, the thick Å¿heathes where-out the flower cometh are berriegreene, and the flames that Å¿pread aboue them are of lack and Å¿ad yellow mingled together, the Å¿teale that goeth betwixt, is verdigreece and berry yellow tempered together.

div.head: CluÅ¿ius his broad leafde bastard flovver de luce.
div.p: The other flower deluce with broade leaues, hath a pale blew flower, more paler then the former, both topt and Å¿hadovved as is moÅ¿t fittinge, the leafe is pale mingled with aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿adyellovv, the bole is pale and Å¿omwhat blackiÅ¿h.

div.head: 6. The yellow flower deluce.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two flower deluces are much differinge in coloure, for the firÅ¿t is a very faire perfect yellow, and may very conveniently be topt and Å¿hadowed as the picture it Å¿elffe declareth the mouthe leaues are whitiÅ¿h be a Å¿omwhat tendinge towardes blew, yet the vpper ribbe appeareth to pale maÅ¿ticot coloure.

div.head: The Å¿paniÅ¿h flovver deluce.
div.p: The other hath whitiÅ¿h leaues, and the borders may be expreÅ¿Å¿ed vvith a little lack and aÅ¿hcoloure mingled, the leaues that Å¿tand vpright vvithin are more blewerâª Å¿pread abroade with purple flames.

div.head: 7. Moly, or the Sorcerers garlieke.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿euerall Å¿ortes of Moly, are both in the flowers and the leaues very different, for the firÅ¿t Å¿orte hath yellow Å¿tarre-lyke flovvers, faire vvithin, but without of a more paler yellovv, the knope vvithin is greeniÅ¿h, the Å¿priggs and knopes that Å¿tand at the end of them are faire yellow, the leaffe is of a browniÅ¿h greene, which may be coloured vvith aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿ad yellow, and Å¿hadowed vvith Å¿apgreene, and the Å¿teale may conveniently be Å¿hadowed vvith mountaine greene.

div.head: Mountaine Moly.
div.p: The other Å¿orte hath purple lyke leaues and may be painted with white and Å¿oetblack, and Å¿hadowed with the Å¿ame, the inner knopes are of maÅ¿ticot yellow, Å¿tanding about a head of light greene, the incloÅ¿ed knopes are reddiÅ¿h, the Å¿teales are a light greene, of verdigreece and mountaine greene mingled together and topt with white.

div.head: 8. The Mountaine Lilly.
div.p: THe mountaine Lilley hath his flower of a vvithered purple coloure, & Å¿hadovved accordingly, and garniÅ¿hed with certaine Å¿ad purple Å¿pots, the Å¿teale hath certaine Å¿potts, but more darkly appearinge.

div.head: 9. Martagon, or Mountaine Lilly.
div.p:
THe Lilly Martagon, called after the name of pomponeus. Is a faire Origne ravvncy, and may be painted with Å¿affron, and Å¿hadowed with lack, and the Ribbes topt vvith white, the Å¿potts are black, and the Å¿priggs
and knopes are white MaÅ¿ticot, the Å¿teales are mountaine greene mingled with a little verdigreece and the leaues alÅ¿o Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene.

div.head: 10. The red Lilly.
div.p: THe red Lilly may be coloured with high maÅ¿ticot and menny, and Å¿hadowed with vermillion and lack; the Å¿potts are black, the blade or bodekin is oker yellow, & Å¿omwhat reddiÅ¿h towardes the pointe, the Å¿priggs are vermillion coloure with a little maÅ¿ticot there vnder, the Å¿teale is mountaine greene mingled with verdigreece; as alÅ¿o thoÅ¿e leaues that are vpon the Å¿teale. The edges are topt with white, the Å¿hadowe may be tempered of Å¿ap-greene and verdigreece, the toppinge of maÅ¿ticot and mountaine-greene.

div.head: 11. Gladiolus Narbonenâª or Corne-flagge.
div.p: THe Corne flagg flowers which are here repreÅ¿ented are little differinge from each other. But this, the one bringes flowers forth but on one Å¿ide; and the other on both Å¿idesâª without they are of a ReddiÅ¿h red, Å¿haddowed vvith lack, appearinge tovvardes the bottom of a pale yellowiÅ¿h coloure, and at the ver â¢ end are redd. The Å¿teale is mountaine greene, as alÅ¿o the leaues that are â¢ on it, yet the Å¿potts or Å¿tipples vpon them are Å¿omevvhat reddiÅ¿h, a â¢ may be Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene.

div.head: CorneÅ¿ â¢ -flovvers leaued on both Å¿ides.
div.p: This flower is alÅ¿o of â¢ le red vvithin, and at the mouth thereof there is a pale whitly Å¿tripe, v â¢â¢ a garland of a bloode red coloure about it, the middlemoÅ¿t bodkin is of a whitiÅ¿h coloure tendinge towardes red, and the Å¿horter Å¿priggs appeare more yellovviÅ¿h.

div.head: 12. The dubble white roÅ¿e.
div.p: THis firÅ¿t being a pleaÅ¿ant and vvell Å¿mellinge roÅ¿e may be painted with leade vvhite, and Å¿hadowed with a little florey, the middle Å¿eedes are of a brovvne oker yellovv toucht onely vvith a little Å¿ad yellow and lack, the Å¿teale is verdigreece onely broken vvith a little maÅ¿ticot, and alÅ¿o the Å¿ide leaues, the veines vvhich goe throughe them are maÅ¿ticott, Å¿hadowed vvith verdigreece. The leaues are to be coloured vvith Å¿ad yellovv & aÅ¿hcoloure and a little florey beinge mingled amonge the Å¿ame, topt vvith a little vvhite amonge the aforeÅ¿aide colours, and Å¿ha â¢â¢ wed Lambe-black, the Å¿teales of the leaues are Å¿omevvhat lighter and tendinge tovvardes yellovv.

div.head: RoÅ¿a Rubra.
div.p: The other roÅ¿e is of a faire light red, and may be Å¿hadovved vvith faire lack, the Å¿eedes are maÅ¿ticott yellovv, Å¿hadovved vvith brovvne oker, the coloure may be tempered vvith comon lack, and topt with vvhite lack.

div.head: 13. The Hollandes roÅ¿e of 100. leaues.
div.p: THe Hollandes roÅ¿e of a hundred leaues is of a faire and goodly â¢â¢ Å¿hcoloure, and may be painted vvith lack and vvhite, and Å¿hadovved vvith lack, and topt vvith vvhite and a little lack amonge the Å¿ame. The Å¿teale is of mountaine greene and a little verdigreece mingled therewith, Å¿hadovved vvith verdigreece and lack, and the little budds may be painted vvith the Å¿ame. The leaffe may be painted vvith Å¿ad yellovv and light aÅ¿hcoloure mingled. The Ribbes vvith verdigreece and Å¿apgreene and in Å¿ome places tempered vvith a little lack.

div.head: The Changeable RoÅ¿e.
div.p: The other Changeable coloured roÅ¿e, is of a light red and vvhite Å¿trypt one within another, and may far better be expreÅ¿Å¿ed by the draught of the penÅ¿ill, then deÅ¿cribed vvith the penne.

div.head: 14. Bell flowers.
div.p: THe flowers of the firÅ¿t Bell flovver, may be painted vvith light Å¿mal â¢ blevv, and Å¿hadowed vvith a little lackmoes, the Å¿priggs are vvhitiÅ¿h tendinge tovvardes yellovv, and vvithin is the flower more paler and vvhitte liar about the knope.

The white Bell flovvers may be painted vvith vvhite and lamb black, the Å¿priggs vvithin are blewiÅ¿h as the former is, the middle knope vvhere the Å¿priggs doe growe vpon is vvhitiÅ¿h greene and hath a pleaÅ¿ â¢ nt greene circle about them. The leaffe is mountaine greene, Å¿hadowed vvith verdigreece, the Å¿prigges that Å¿tand out are more paler, and topt with white and maÅ¿ticot mingled vnder the aforeÅ¿aide coloures.

div.head: 15. Poppie flowers.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿ort â¢ s of Poppie flowers which are here expreÅ¿t, the firÅ¿t is white; and the Å¿econd carnation coloure, beinge very dubble and conÅ¿iÅ¿tinge of very many leaues, and may be painted vvith menny & vermillion, being topt vvith vermilion and vvhite, and Å¿hadowed vvith faire lack and a little vermilion amonge the Å¿ame, but the lovveÅ¿t Å¿hadowe may be drawne with faire vermilioÌ, & for the better glanÅ¿inge of them the middle knope is of yellow oker, & in the middle of it mountaine greene.

div.head: 16 Wilde roÅ¿e Campion, being dubble.
div.p: WIlde roÅ¿e Campion beinge dubble leafde is very delectable to beholde, and may be painted with roÅ¿e red, and topt vpon the endes of the flames with a little lack onder the Å¿ame. The Å¿hadowe is like vnto black velvett, and Å¿potts or Å¿tripes coloured vvith highcoloured lack. The leaff is light mountaine greene and white mingled together, topt vvith white, and Å¿hadowed with verdigreece and mountaine greene.

div.head: The Å¿ingle VVild-roÅ¿e Campion.
div.p: The Å¿ingle one is of a white coloure, aÅ¿well in the leaues, as the teeth in the middle. It may be Å¿hadowed with thinne black florey the veines beinge Å¿omewhat greeniÅ¿h.

div.head: 17. Whyte Sweet Williams.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e flowers is white, and may be coloured with leade white and a little redd in Å¿uch wiÅ¿e that it very hardly may be perceived, the garland is of a faire blood red and towardes the middle a little ruÅ¿Å¿ett, the â¢ aggs are white with a little lack coloure, the garland may be Å¿hadowed with a little browne red, the Å¿eedebole is of light mountaine greene the Å¿priggs are Å¿omewhat a light yellow. The leaff is of mountaine greene and aÅ¿hcoloure, and Å¿hadowed with verdigreene.

div.head: Single Å¿vveete VVilliams.
div.p: The other is fleÅ¿hcoloure or cornation red, and towardes the middle it is almoÅ¿t white, the jagges are at the endes of a carnation coloure, the Å¿eede bole is mountaine greene, and Å¿hadowed with verdigreene, but the knope or b â¢ dde at the end is lack coloure, the Å¿heath of the flower is like vnto the Å¿eedebole, the Å¿teale is verdigreece, and the leaues are Å¿omewhat lighter.

div.head: 18. Carnations or: cloue gilleflowers.
div.p: THeÅ¿e three very faire great dubble Carnations or clouegille flowers, are exceedinge pleaÅ¿ant to looke vpon, moÅ¿t differing in the diverÅ¿itie of theire coloures, the firÅ¿t is white with Å¿ome red lack Å¿potts finely adorned. The Iaggs are alÅ¿o white, the Socquet or Å¿heath of the flower is mountaine greene, and Å¿hadowed with verdigreece. The Å¿teale is verdigreece Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene, the leaff is of a pale mountaine greene, appearinge Å¿omewhat blewiÅ¿h.

div.head: The red Carnation.
div.p: The middle flower of the three is perfect blood red.

div.head: The vvhite Carnation.
div.p: The laÅ¿t of theÅ¿e is white as Å¿now, & may be coloured vvith leade white, and lightly Å¿hadowed with browne blew.

div.head: 19. The flower Gith: or nigella.
div.p: THe flower Melanthium or Nigella, and called in dutch NarduÅ¿zaet, is here repreÅ¿ented in two Å¿everall formes. The firÅ¿t hath Å¿ingle flowers, being whitiÅ¿h & tendinge towarde a blew aÅ¿hcoloure, havinge blew veines with white lagges and Å¿prigges, the Å¿eede bole beinge of a pale greene, beinge curled in the middle.

div.head: The dubble Nigella.
div.p: The other Å¿orte bringes forth a flower that is dubble like vnto the former in coloure, but about the Å¿eedebole the leaues are more purple like. The Å¿teale and the leaues may be coloured with light aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿ad yellow, and topt with white, and Å¿hadowed with verdigreece, the forme of the flower is much after the faÅ¿hion of the blew dubble ruffes that are dubble Å¿ett about mens necks.

div.head: 20. The great dubble Carnations or Gilleflowers.
div.p: THe greateÅ¿t dubble Gilleflower, or dubble carnation, is a very faire and goodly flower to looke vpon. So that the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e two is of a faire fleÅ¿hcoloure & Å¿pred over with a little whiter fleÅ¿hcoloure, the Å¿haddow of pale lack coloure tempered with a little vermilion very Å¿oftly and dilicately haÌdled, but in Å¿ome high Å¿hadowes, onely toucht with a browne red, there doe fall in Å¿oÌe Å¿male Å¿potts of lack coloure, but caÌ hardly be obÅ¿erved.

div.head: The greateÅ¿t changeable Carnation flovver.
div.p: The other is beÅ¿ides his faire greatneÅ¿Å¿e very fairely Å¿tript & may be painted with leadewhite, Å¿omewhat Å¿ilverlike, and dravvinge the flames vvith faire lack, the broader Å¿omewhat lighter, & the narrower Å¿omewhat Å¿adder. The Å¿haddow being tempered of blew, and the Å¿eedebole is of mountaine greene, Å¿hadowed with verdigreece, but at the knope there is a Å¿male beÅ¿princklinge of lack coloure, the Å¿teale is Å¿omwhat Å¿adder, & betweene the ioyntes are Å¿ome lighter Å¿pottes of verdigreece, the leaffe is alÅ¿o mountaine greeneâª Å¿hadowed with Å¿paniÅ¿h greene, and topt vvith a little white.

div.head: THE THIRDE BOOKE CONTAININGE THE DISCRIPTION OF THE FLOVVERS IN AVTVMNE, MADE BY THE AVTHOR AFORESAIDE.

q.l: If that theÅ¿e workes Å¿hall well content,
Thy curiouÅ¿e mynde and SenÅ¿e:
Be mindfull of the Authors praiÅ¿e
And iudge of his exÅ¿pence.

div.head: 1. Clematis, or the travellers ioy.
div.p: CLematis is a twiggie growth, and this flower is called by CluÅ¿ius a Å¿econde woodbyne, firÅ¿t the flower cometh vp like vnto red Ivy, and afterwardes groweth more twigg-like, the branches are of a CheÅ¿nut coloure, the Å¿maler braunches or Å¿teales where vpon the leaues depende and growe vp, are very Å¿male and tender, and are very brittle. The flower is very tender, and withereth aÅ¿Å¿oone as it is broken of, as experiece teacheth vs, it is incloÅ¿ed in longe knopes that are of a very light Å¿kie coloure and purple like. This flower openeth in the middle, and it hath 3. furrowes in it, which almoÅ¿t by the knope is of a light greene: And this flower may be painted after this manner, firÅ¿t take faire lack coloure, put therevnto a little Lambeblack, becauÅ¿e the purple may falle Å¿omewhat Å¿ad, the Å¿potts are light greene mingled with aÅ¿hcoloure and maÅ¿ticot, the Å¿yde leaues are of a lighter greene, the leaues are of a light aÅ¿h coloure mingled vvith Å¿ad yellovv, the Å¿teales of the leaues are greene, the braunches or twiggs that beareth the flower are cheÅ¿nut coloure.

div.head: 2. The muÅ¿ke roÅ¿e.
div.p: THis roÅ¿e is perfect white a little tending towardes a whay coloure, within it hath yellow veines, the leaffe and Å¿teale is euen, and Å¿mooth, with very few prickes, which are of a cheÅ¿nut coloure the Å¿teale is a lighter greene then the leaues are, the leaues may be painted with Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿hyninge, and vpon the wronge Å¿ide, not Å¿o Å¿ad a greene but Å¿omewhat lighter beinge mingled with white and mountains greene, the Å¿teale of the roÅ¿e is of a CheÅ¿nut coloure, & it may be painted vvith a little lack and oker.

div.head: 3. The mary golde of the Å¿onne.
div.p:
THis great and faire Å¿onne marigolde cometh late, not before September,
and althoughe this be a very great flower, yet it groweth yearely vp, of a Å¿male Å¿eede, and muÅ¿t be new Å¿owen every yeare.

div.head: The leÅ¿Å¿er marigolde of peru.
div.p: This Å¿maler is in all thinges like vnto the former, but is of a Å¿horter growth, and there ariÅ¿eth of theÅ¿e three or foure of them vpon one Å¿teale and of one Å¿eede.

The leaues that Å¿tand rounde about are of a faire maÅ¿ticott coloure, and if the maÅ¿ticot be not of a high coloure, it muÅ¿t be tempered with a little lack, made Å¿hyninge, and Å¿hadovved with Å¿ad yellow, the innermoÅ¿t muÅ¿t be of a berry yellow there muÅ¿t be regard had in toppinge the Å¿tarrs vvith light maÅ¿ticott, the laggs muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be topt with the former coloure, the cowne within is the Å¿addeÅ¿t of all, the leaues that come after the yellovv leaues, muÅ¿t very evidently appeare, becauÅ¿e they are greene, theÅ¿e leaues and the Å¿teale muÅ¿t be Å¿hadowed vvith Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿hcoloure, and topt with white and maÅ¿ticott.

div.head: 4. The Indian Reede.
div.p: THe flower of this Indian Reede, is golde yellow and Å¿potted with black Å¿potts, the leaues are like vnto white nieÅ¿inge pouder, and may be coloured with mountaine greene & maÅ¿ticott, the middle ribbe is Å¿omewhat whiter, the Å¿trepes thereof are of Å¿apgreene, & Å¿hadowed with a little verdigreece amonge the other, the roote is of a CheÅ¿nut coloure, the tvvo reedes are coloured with the Å¿ap of berry yellow, and Å¿hadowed vvith Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿hcoloure.

div.head: 5. The great Affricaen, or french Marigolde.
div.p: THis great french marygolde is of a very faire growth, and hardly will growe in this clymate by reaÅ¿on of the colde, for it growes vp very Å¿lowely, with Å¿ingle leaues Å¿preade abroade, Å¿ett like a ruffe, and muÅ¿t be coloured with operement, and topt with maÅ¿ticott, and Å¿hadowed with lack & Å¿ad yellow, the middle crowne is of a Å¿traw coloure or light yellow, tendinge towardes maÅ¿ticot, and Å¿hadowed with Å¿ad yellow. The Å¿teale and leaffe muÅ¿t be coloured with the Å¿ap & iuice of verdigreece and Å¿hadowed vvith verdigreece and Å¿apgreene, the budde is mingled vvith a little operement at the toppe, and is Å¿hadovved as is a foreÅ¿aide, the Å¿teale belovv hath Å¿ome reddiÅ¿h Å¿tripes.

div.head: 6. The dubble french Marygolde.
div.p: THe great dubble french Mary golde differeth nothinge from the former, but onely that it is thicker of leaves and hath a Å¿hyninge gloÅ¿Å¿e, and muÅ¿t beÅ¿hadowed brightly.

div.head: 7. The little french Marigolde.
div.p: THe little french marigolde is of a high and bright coloure Å¿hyninge, topt with operement and maÅ¿ticot reÅ¿emblinge golde, the Å¿hadowinge of the leaues vpon the Å¿ides appeareth like red velvett, and of Å¿ome there fore they be called velvett flowers, in the temperinge of the coloures, there muÅ¿t be vÅ¿ed good lack, a little vermilion, and operement, the greater of theÅ¿e two Å¿ortes reÅ¿embleth much velvet: as is aforeÅ¿aide. The borders of the leaues are of maÅ¿ticot yellow, the leafe is of a yellow oker and aÅ¿hcoloure mingled, and it muÅ¿t be Å¿hadowed accordingly, the Å¿teales of the leaues are lighter then the leaues themÅ¿elues, the great Å¿talke is Å¿adder then the leaues, the knope is more yellowiÅ¿h, the roote is Å¿omewhat reddiÅ¿h.

div.head: 8. Mallowes, or dubble hollihock.
div.p: THe dubble hollihock, is a very pleaÅ¿ant coloured flower, of a vvhitiÅ¿h fleÅ¿hcoloure, the edges more lighter then the middle, with Å¿ome Å¿male Å¿tripes in the middle like vnto the vermillion coloure, Å¿princkled with a little lack: the higheÅ¿t toppinge of this flower muÅ¿t Å¿hyne white like vnto Å¿ilver coloure. The leaffe is of a Comon greene Å¿omewhat yellovviÅ¿h, the knopes are of a paler greene more whiter, the Å¿teale is more yellower, and all theÅ¿e muÅ¿t be tempered accordinge to theire owne proprietie, the pointe of the openinge budde muÅ¿t be topt a little whyter then the leaues, the lagg of the buddes be of lighter greene then the leaues be aboue.

The other Å¿orte of this full leafde flower is of the coloure of a Rubie, it is painted with lack and vermillion, and topt with white and vermillion,
and Å¿hadovved vvith faire Å¿ad coloured lack. The buddes where they appeare throughe are as faire red as the flovver, the Å¿teale and the leaffe is like vnto the former.

div.head: 9. French curled Mallowe.
div.p: THe French curled Mallovve, is of a very Å¿trange and crooked grovvth, the flowers in the huÅ¿kes are hardely te be eÅ¿pied, of a red fleÅ¿hcoloure, the huÅ¿kes are greene, of maÅ¿ticot and light aÅ¿hcoloure, the leaues are of the Å¿ame coloure, yet Å¿omewhat Å¿adder, the Å¿haddow Å¿apgreene, the curled edges, are topt more whiter then the leaffe is, and alÅ¿o the veines of the leaues too. The Å¿teales are light aÅ¿hgreene and Å¿hadowed with Å¿apgreene.

div.head: 10. Palma ChriÅ¿ti, or kick.
div.p: KIck, is a verry Å¿trange & vnuÅ¿uall growth, the Å¿teale is like vnto wood, the leaues thereof a Å¿ad and vnpleaÅ¿ant greene (it is called of Å¿ome the mole or the moldwarps herbe becauÅ¿e they eate there of) it may be painted with Å¿ad yellovv and florey for it is a blackiÅ¿h morphen coloure, and yet in the reflection there may be Å¿eene a whitiÅ¿h coloure at theire vppermoÅ¿t toppinge; The vppermoÅ¿t budds at the top are of a berrie greene, and are Å¿hadowed with Å¿ad oker and omber, the appearance of the buddes at the top are of a purple coloure, the open budds at the Å¿ides and the flower is of light maÅ¿ticot. The great budds at the Å¿ides which is the Å¿eede is the braunched budds, being of a Å¿ad mountaine greene coloure, the Å¿teale is of a BraÅ¿ill coloure Å¿trewed as it were with white meale, the Ioyntes are reddiÅ¿h of lack coloure and the Å¿teales of the Å¿eede buddee are greene.

div.head: 11. The Mexican flower, or the wonder of peru.
div.p: THis vvonder of peru, is found in India, and is in our daies by the matiners (that are this may addicted) brought into theÅ¿e countries, and is reckoned and eÅ¿teemed for a vvonder in regard of the alteration of the coloures, there are of them of dyvers Å¿ortes, Å¿ome of theire flowers of Å¿ad lack coloure, and alÅ¿o the great budds, and are topped vvith lack and white together, the veines and the knopes are a little blewiÅ¿h, the little budds are greene like vnto the leaues, and the Å¿teales of Å¿ome of them appeare red, like vnto the flower of the buddes as the others doe. The leaffe and Å¿teale is greene, of aÅ¿hcoloure and maÅ¿ticott, and are Å¿hadowed vvith verdigreece.

The other flower of this Å¿orte, is checkered, Å¿ome of the leaues within are of lack coloure, and others are of white and maÅ¿ticott, and Å¿o are they that are folded hanging downewardes, and are marbled with Å¿ome Å¿tripes or veines of pale lack coloure. The Å¿teale of the flower, euen to the flower, is coloured as the flower is, the Å¿talke and leaues are greene like vnto the other.

div.head: 12. Tobacco, or Henbane of peru.
div.p: TObacco in theÅ¿e Countries is more comon then in the daies of out forefathers, it is of a high growth, the leaues may very well bepainted vvith Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿hcoloure, and Å¿hadowed vvith verdigreece, the budds are of a Å¿ad greene when they firÅ¿t appeare, & when the flowers Å¿hewes it Å¿elff, then are they of a maÅ¿ticote greene, the flower is vnderneath a pleaÅ¿ant greene, almoÅ¿t a yellow greene, the flower is within lack coloure and white, in the hallowneÅ¿Å¿e of the flower it is a yellowiÅ¿h greene, vvith a blewiÅ¿h greene budde.

div.head: 13. Rounde Sowbread.
div.p: THis flower is called the Italian Swynes breade, and that becauÅ¿e of the roote thereof, the coloure tendes tovvard a purple lack, and about the bottom where the leaues Å¿pringe out it is Å¿omwhat Å¿adder, the leaues towardes theire endes are Å¿omwhat brighter, the wrethen Å¿teales are cheÅ¿nut colour, the leafe is a pleaÅ¿ant greene, havinge whitiÅ¿h, flames, in the middle Å¿omewhat darker, and not Å¿o Å¿hyninge as the others are. TheÅ¿e leaues muÅ¿t be painted with browne aÅ¿hcoloure, & Å¿ad yellow mingled together, Å¿haddowed with Å¿apgreene, the white flames are of maÅ¿ticot and leade vvhite mingled together, the topping a little brighter and whiter, and a little Å¿ad greene in the middle.

The Roote of this Italians Sow breade is of a CheÅ¿nut coloure, the vppermoÅ¿t Å¿priggs aboue are Å¿omwhat lighter the Å¿teales of the leaues are, the
Å¿haddow is a black red, or of omber and black and browne red together, the toppinge is a little white mingled vnder the aforeÅ¿aide coloures. The little leaues are like alÅ¿o vnto the former little leaues of the flower.

div.head: 14. Ivy Sow breade.
div.p: THe Sowbread wth many leaues, is the greateÅ¿t of all theÅ¿e yt are knowne by that name. The coloure of theÅ¿e flowers is painted with fleÅ¿hcoloure, and Å¿hadowed with purple lack coloure, and that in Å¿peciall towardes the lower heades of the flowers, they are topt with a pale purple coloure, the Å¿teales are a cheÅ¿nut coloure and Å¿omewhat purple like, the buddes betwixt the leaues are greene, and when they are Å¿pronge out, they be of a purple coloure, Concerninge the leaues, they are much at one with the leaues of the former Sowe breade, but yet theire greene is tendinge Å¿omewhat towardes mountaine greene, and althoughe that greene be the lighteÅ¿t, yet the Å¿potts are the Å¿addeÅ¿t.

The Roote of this Å¿ow breade is almoÅ¿t like vnto the former, but that it is more blacker, and it may be painted with lampe black and red-black very thinne layde vpon it, and Å¿hadowed Å¿omewhat Å¿adder. The Å¿teale and leaues are as it is Å¿aide in theire diÅ¿cription, but the buddes that are a little open may be Å¿eene a little light red appearinge out, the Å¿haddowe of the bole is as the former but a litte Å¿adder, the toppinge is of white and a little lamblack, and the veines are more blacker.

div.head: 15. The great winter Daffodill: or NarciÅ¿Å¿us flower.
div.p: THis NarciÅ¿Å¿us cometh in the harveÅ¿t and is called the great winter daffodill. The one is thicker of leaues then the other, the Å¿ingle one is of the coloure of maÅ¿ticot being thinly laid on, Å¿hadowed vvith Å¿ad yellovv, the knobes in the flower are like vnto maÅ¿ticott, but the Å¿priggs wherevpon the little knobes doe Å¿tand are of a light greene. The Å¿teale or Å¿tumpe where the flower comes forth of, is of a pale maÅ¿ticot yellow at the vpper parte of it, but below it is of a pale greene, & is painted with Å¿ad yellow & aÅ¿hcoloure, and Å¿hadowed with omber and Å¿ad yellow and a little black red altogether, and the veine muÅ¿t well be obÅ¿erved that paÅ¿Å¿eth throughe the middle of the leaues, becauÅ¿e of there Å¿hyninge glance.

div.head: NarciÅ¿Å¿us, or the dubble vvinter Daffodill.
div.p: The dubble one, is like vnto the laÅ¿t mentioned daffodill in coloure, nothinge differing therein, but that it is more thicker of leaues, and fevver greene leaues then the other hath.

div.head: 16. The winter Iacynth.
div.p: THis Winter Iacynth, may be coloured with Indigo & lack mingled together, but at the Å¿harpe endes of the flowers, there be certaine Å¿tripes of a Å¿ad browne coloure, and the more inwarde the more lighter: the threedes that Å¿tand within the flower are almoÅ¿t as Å¿ad indigo, the Å¿teale is of a pale verdigreece coloure, the Å¿male Å¿priggs wherevpon the flowers growe, are aboue almoÅ¿t like vnto indigo, and below are greene, and when the buddes beginne to open, it is reddiÅ¿h vnder the Å¿teale it is of a reddiÅ¿h purple, the Å¿eedebole is red, and topt with white, the two longe leaues are yellovviÅ¿h. The bunche and the Å¿teale is as the other aforeÅ¿aide is.

div.head: The greater vvinter Iacynth.
div.p: The coloure of this great winter Iacynth, is, (concerninge the coloure), agreeinge to the former, onelie it it of a greater proportion, and hath tvvo Å¿teales, the one againÅ¿t the other, and the budds black, the Å¿eedebole is like the former, but Å¿omewhat whyter.

div.head: 17. Fever few, or fedder few.
div.p: THe Å¿ingle and the dubble of theÅ¿e are both of one coloure, the middle crowne is Å¿ad yellow, mingled with a little white, the leaues are almoÅ¿t white, the braunches are lightgreene, and the leaffe is a Å¿adder greene, and is painted with Å¿ad yellow and aÅ¿hcoloure, or the lighteÅ¿t maÅ¿ticott and aÅ¿hcoloure.
The dubble is like vnto the former, of a pure white & very many Å¿male leaues, in the crowne of it there is a Å¿pott of a faire greeniÅ¿h yellow.

div.head: 18. Doggs bane, or purple medow Å¿affron, or the Å¿onne before the father.
div.p: THis flower commeth in harveÅ¿t, is of a faire red & purple colour, it may well be painted with tourneÅ¿ol and white tempered together and Å¿hadowed with lack, there goeth a white Å¿tripe within throughe the leaues, the Å¿priggs that Å¿tand within the flower are vvhitiÅ¿h, the little knopes on the end of thoÅ¿e Å¿priggs are oker yellow topt with maÅ¿ticote. The Å¿teale is to the bottom of a Å¿ilver colour, the budds when they opeÌ are whitiÅ¿h coloured.

div.head: The vvhite meddovv Å¿affron.
div.p: The other Å¿orte of theÅ¿e flowers is pure white, and is painted with white leade, and topt with that white whichs is called the Å¿chillffer white, and Å¿haddowed very thinne with a blewiÅ¿h black, the tongues have theire heades of a maÅ¿ticott yellow; and the Å¿priggs of thoÅ¿e tongues are whitiÅ¿h. The Å¿teale of the flower is white from the top to the toe, and the budds likewiÅ¿e, onely the vppermoÅ¿t parte of the Å¿teale hard by the flower is a maidens bluÅ¿h coloure.

div.head: 19. Saffron of conÅ¿tance, with broad leaves.
div.p: THis flower when it firÅ¿t appeareth is of a red purple coloure marked with Å¿potts of a Å¿ad lack coloure, but havinge Å¿toode a while opeÌ, theÌ are thoÅ¿e Å¿potts very euen, Å¿o that they can hardely be marked where they were, the coloure towardes the ende of the Å¿teale is of a white Å¿ilver coloure the neck is of a vvhitiÅ¿h yellow, but more lower it is of a reddiÅ¿h yellow, and agreeinge with the coloure of the drie earth.

div.head: Checkered Å¿affron flovvers.
div.p: This SpaniÅ¿h Å¿affron that is Å¿o checkered, is a Å¿peties of the ConÅ¿tantinoples Å¿affron, but his leaves are much leÅ¿Å¿er, and with Å¿ad red lack Å¿potts checkered like the checkered daffodill the Å¿eede bole is almoÅ¿t of the Å¿ame faÅ¿hion, the flower may be coloured with a fleÅ¿h coloure grounde, being lightly laide on with faire red Å¿tryped checkers and Å¿potts devided Å¿o towardes the end of the flower, the Å¿teale is perfect white as the comon Å¿affron is.

div.head: 20. SpaniÅ¿h mountaine Å¿affron flowers, of divers colours.
div.p: SAffron of dyvers coloures groweth cloÅ¿e to the grounde with three or foure flowers together, as though it were all but one flower, but Å¿tanding platted as it were the one leaffe purple, an other halffe purple, another perfect white another but halffe white, as in the figure you may perceiue: devided with Å¿potts and Å¿haddowes, the outtermoÅ¿t leaffe is very beautifull, flamed cleane through with murrey flames, whichs in the middle of the leaffe are all even Å¿o that no flame can be Å¿eene, the coloure of this flower, is a purple tending towardes a tourniÅ¿ol the pointinges even and thinne, and Å¿hadowed with pale lack, and in Å¿ome places Å¿hadowed more Å¿adly, the peÅ¿teales are maÅ¿ticot yellow; the huÅ¿ke where out the flowers doe come forth of, is of a reddiÅ¿h coloure.

div.head: Mountaine Å¿affron.
div.p: The Å¿paniÅ¿h Å¿affron is of a more Å¿adder coloure theÌ others are, but yet of one proportion, but for changinge of the purple coloure you muÅ¿t take aÅ¿hcoloured lack and white leade together, and Å¿haddow theÅ¿e accordingly as is aforeÅ¿aide, the clappers that come in the middle, temper them with a little oker and Å¿ad yellow, the leaves are topt with white and verdigreece, the greene colour that goeth over the cod is an eveÌ whitiÅ¿h greene but the cod or the Å¿heath it Å¿elffe is more greener, the Å¿teale is reddiÅ¿h, the bole may be painted like roeÅ¿t or browne red.

The leaÅ¿t & Å¿horteÅ¿t portugals Å¿affron, the leaues without are of a faire fleÅ¿h coloure drawne throughe the middle with one line of Indigo and with in of a whiter fleÅ¿h colour in the line appearinge a greene Å¿hynings throughe the other coloure, the oudd at his firÅ¿t aryÅ¿inge is maydens bluÅ¿h coloure with Å¿pringinge out Å¿priggs with yellow knobes, the bole is as the former.

div.head: 21. Saffron of naples.
div.p: NAples Å¿affron is of a reddiÅ¿h purple, painted with aÅ¿h coloure and lack mingled together, and topt with a little white leade amongÅ¿t the former, this flower hath Å¿ome Å¿potts but they are very hardly Å¿eene, and are of a faire lack coloure, the Å¿teale is Å¿ilver coloure, the knopes are of oke â¢ yellow, topt with maÅ¿ticott.

div.head: Dubble leafde Å¿affron.
div.p: This is of a pale purple, and here and there hath white flames and Å¿ometymes browne flames or raies; the buddes are maÅ¿ticot yellow, the Å¿teale is almoÅ¿t white; and topt with Å¿ilver white, but towardes the bottom it is more lighter.

div.head: 22. The vnpleaÅ¿ant, whitered or decayed Iacynth.
div.p: THis is a Å¿trange and a rare Iacynth, it hath white leaves, and muÅ¿t be painted with ocket-yellow and purple mingled together, and a little aÅ¿h colour amonge the Å¿ame, the buddes are of the Å¿ame colloure, and the Å¿hadowinge is well repreÅ¿ented in the figure it Å¿elffe, the laggs below are aÅ¿h-coloure, and within the flowers are of a Å¿hyninge aÅ¿h coloure, the Å¿teale is of the Å¿ame coloure, with a Å¿hyninge Å¿hadowe, and Å¿o are the leaves. The leaffe is mountaine greene, Å¿hadovved vvith Å¿ad yellovv and aÅ¿h coloure, the boles coloured vvith aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿haddovved with omber, the other half are milkwhite leaves, the Å¿teale is of a light greene, and the leaves like vnto the other.

div.head: 23. Comon Saffron.
div.p: THe flower of this Comon Å¿affron, is of a blewiÅ¿h purple Å¿omevvhat light, mingled with Å¿ad purple flames cominge by degrees froÌ the middle, they are of a light aÅ¿hcoloure mingled with lack and white leade, the flames are indifferent Å¿ad, and may be painted vvith Indigo and lack, but towardes the middle Å¿omewhat Å¿adder as like vnto red purple. The Å¿priggs are almoÅ¿t blood red. For the Saffron is vermillion red and Å¿hadowed with lack, the middle Å¿priggs are maÅ¿ticott yellow, and topt Å¿omewhat lighter.
The other is like vnto this, but is a little lighter.

div.head: 24. ConÅ¿tantinoples mountaine Å¿affron.
div.p: THis Å¿affron hath a very odd flower, and may be coloured with faire tourniÅ¿ol, mingled with a litle white lead, and topt with the Å¿ame, the Å¿hadow of Indigo and lack, the huÅ¿ke from whence the flower cometh out of, is like the Å¿ame. The bole is of a pale yellow, vvith white Å¿potts, and Å¿hadowed vvith omber. The longeÅ¿t huÅ¿ke tends toward a Å¿ilver coloure, it hath a Å¿hort Å¿teale, and at the lower end it is whitiÅ¿h.

div.head: 25. The Å¿trange daffodill: or the vnknowne NarciÅ¿Å¿us.
div.p: THis Å¿trange & vnknowne NarciÅ¿Å¿us, is called by Doctor CluÅ¿ius, NarciÅ¿Å¿us La â¢â¢ folio Major, and is of a purple coloure, Å¿omewhat tendinge tovvardes a Å¿kie coloure, havinge two white hornes, with reddiÅ¿h yellovv Å¿eedes, the Å¿teales of the flowers are of a Å¿hyninge, yet a withered greene coloure. The huÅ¿ke that incloÅ¿ed the flower is of a pale greene. The bole is as bigg as a mans fiÅ¿te, but therein there is no difference betwixt this & the Comon NarciÅ¿Å¿us, and may be painted with a little white and oker together, the Å¿hadowe is of omber and browne blew, the veines are like the earth & are Å¿haddowed vvith omber, the vpper neck is devided into Å¿hilffers which muÅ¿t be Å¿eperated vvith a little omber from the other parte, the vppermoÅ¿t top is a yellovviÅ¿h vvhite.

div.trailer: Here endeth the flowers in Autumne.
