div.head: THE FOVRTH AND LAST BOOKE CONTAININGE A DISCRIPTION OF THE FLOVVERS OF THE WINTER QVARTER.

q.l: If hethertoe (my frende) you haue,
Performde the taÅ¿ke in hand:
With ioy proceede, this laÅ¿t will be
The beÅ¿t, when all is Å¿cande.

div.head: 1. Mountaine Pepper.
div.p: THeÅ¿e two Å¿ortes of Pepper, the firÅ¿t beinge called a lawrell Pepper, becauÅ¿e of the likeneÅ¿Å¿e of theÅ¿e leaues with the lawrell leaffe, the one reÅ¿emblinge the other, but yet the lawrell Pepper-flovver hath a Å¿male longe leaffe of a pale greene coloure. The leaues both in forme faÅ¿hion and coloure agree with the leaues of the lawrell tree, the braunches are of a Å¿ad haire coloure, and may be painted with omber, and white mingled together, and are Å¿hadowed and topt, as Å¿uch requireth.

div.head: Mezereon.
div.p: The other which is called Mezereon, hath both Å¿maller leaues and flowers, of a Å¿hyninge light purple, vvhich may be painted with vvhite and lack coloure mingled together, the budds are of a Å¿adder lack coloure, the Å¿teale is as the former is.

div.head: 3. Black neeÅ¿inge pouder, or pellitorie of Å¿panie.
div.p: THe flower of the Helleborus, or black neeÅ¿inge pouder is white, onely vpon Å¿ome Å¿ides there is an appearance of maidens bluÅ¿h coloure, and the leaues at theire endes are of the Å¿ame coloure. The veines are Å¿novv white, but they haue Å¿male Å¿potts of a light maÅ¿ticot yellow, & the grounde of them is greeniÅ¿h, the Å¿teale is of berrie greene, Å¿hadowed vvith Å¿apgreene, the leaues agree with the leaues of the lawrell treeâª and are a little Iaggd from the middle vnto the pointes of them.

div.head: 3. BaÅ¿tard black Hellebor.
div.p:
THe flower of this BaÅ¿tard Hellebor, is of a yellowiÅ¿h greene, and may
may be painted with berrie greene, very thinne lay de vpon it, and Å¿hadowed vvith Å¿apgreene, but vvith great conÅ¿ideration of the veines and Å¿male Å¿tripes, that they be not too groÅ¿ly handled, the toppinge muÅ¿t be of light maÅ¿ticot, the Å¿eedes in the middle are as the former, the Å¿teale is of a light greene, and the leaues Å¿omewhat Å¿adder, and may be painted with aÅ¿hcoloure and Å¿ad yellow together, and with the Å¿ame both Å¿hadowed and topt by diÅ¿cretion.

div.head: 4. Bulbed violetts, or bulbed Å¿tockgillo flowers.
div.p: HEre is expreÅ¿Å¿ed three Å¿ortes of Å¿tock gilloflowers, differinge, but very little froÌ each other, the firÅ¿t hath a white flower of Å¿ix leaues, whereof the three outermoÅ¿t are longer then the other, & the three middle moÅ¿t beinge Å¿horter are cloven in the middle, and garniÅ¿hed with a border of a light greene coloure. The Å¿teale & the leaffe is of a pale greene, the boles are of a light maiden haire coloure tendinge Å¿omewhat whitiÅ¿h. The Seconde of theÅ¿e, is called by the name of the ConÅ¿tantinople violetts or Å¿tockgillo flowers, beinge (thoughe Å¿maller,) both in the flower, leaffe and Å¿teale reÅ¿emblinge the other greater.

The thirde & laÅ¿t of theÅ¿e, is differinge from the two former in the leafe, and in the flower, the vpright Å¿tandinge leaues, are of a Å¿ad greene, and may be painted with Å¿apgreene and indigo, & Å¿ad yellow for the Å¿haddow of it, the flower is pure white and Å¿haddowed with a Å¿ad blew, the Å¿priggs within are of a faire yellow, Å¿tanding round about a Å¿male white hole, the Å¿teale as alÅ¿o the leaues are all of one coloure.

div.head: 5. Yellow winter wolueÅ¿bane.
div.p: THis winter wolueÅ¿bane hath a yellow flower, & is topt with maÅ¿ticot, and is Å¿hadowed with yellow oker, and omber mingled together, the knopes are greeniÅ¿h. The Å¿teale may be coloured with aÅ¿h-coloure and Å¿ad yellow beinge lightly mingled together, and is of a lighter greene then the leaues be, the leafe that is folded downewardes is yet Å¿omewat lighter, the yonge ones at there firÅ¿t cominge out of the ground are more yellower The roote is of a verry deepe and Å¿ad browne ruddy coloure.

div.head: 6. Golden trefoile, or 3. leafde liverworte, or the herbe Trinitie.
div.p: OF theÅ¿e trefoiles beinge of partie coloures that is of red and blew. The firÅ¿t hath a flower of Å¿ix leaues of a faire red coloure, and may be coloured with a thinne braÅ¿ill red, and may be Å¿hadowed with lack & blew mingled together, the knopes & Å¿priggs in the middle are white, the Å¿eedes are a light greene and garniÅ¿hed with pearles that are white, the ondermoÅ¿t leaues are vvhite, vvith a little appearame of red amonge the Å¿ame. The Å¿teale is of a light Sapgreene, but harde at the leaves (vvhich are of a Å¿adder coloure of an aÅ¿h-coloure and Å¿ad yellovv mingled together) are Å¿omewhat reddiÅ¿h tendinge towardes the lack colour, the roote is maydeÌ haire coloure, and may be repreÅ¿ented with red and omber mingled together.

div.head: The blevv Hepatica, or trefoile, &c.
div.p: The other of theÅ¿e flovvers is of a Å¿kie coloure, & is topt and Å¿haddovved as is requiÅ¿ite, in all thinges like vnto the former exceptinge the coloure.

div.head: 7. Saffron with a Å¿ilver coloured flower.
div.p: THeÅ¿e Saffron flowers which are here repreÅ¿ented, are of two Å¿everall coloures, and of either Å¿orte, they are Å¿ingle, and dubble. The firÅ¿t are of a light white coloure, and are Å¿o on the outÅ¿ides, but are garniÅ¿hed with Å¿tripps of a tawney coloure euen to the Å¿teale.

div.head: Saffron vvith golden Å¿trypt leaues.
div.p: The other are of a golde yellow colour with Å¿ad purple Å¿trypes, the boles are of aÅ¿hcoloure, &c.

div.head: 8. The little NarciÅ¿Å¿us.
div.p:
THeÅ¿e little NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers, all of them are reckoned amonge the BaÅ¿tard NarciÅ¿Å¿us flowers. The flowers are withoutt Å¿mell, of the
coloure of faire maÅ¿ticott yellow. The leaffe is of a light greene, of maÅ¿ticot and aÅ¿hcoloure mingled, and is Å¿hadowed as is requiÅ¿ite.

div.head: Saffron vvith golden Å¿trypt leaues.
div.p: This great one, is like vnto the little one in colour, and may be topt with light maÅ¿ticott, and Å¿hadovved with Å¿affron, or elÅ¿e vvith a little Å¿ad yellow and lack coloure.

div.head: 9. The dubble yellow RuÅ¿hey baÅ¿tard NarciÅ¿sus or Daffodill.
div.p: TWo Å¿everall Å¿ortes of baÅ¿tard NarciÅ¿Å¿us are here repreÅ¿ented, that are RuÅ¿hey. They differ moÅ¿t in the coloure of the flowers, for the firÅ¿t hath a yellovv Å¿ockett, and may be painted vvith light maÅ¿ticott, vÅ¿inge therevnto a more Å¿adder coloure for the Å¿hadowinge of it.

The other of theÅ¿e two flowers is white, and needeth no diÅ¿cription for the paintinge of it, the knopes vvithin are yellow, onely of ocker coloure, the Å¿kinne or Å¿heath from whence the flovver cometh forth, is of a light mayden haire coloure, the Å¿heath is light greene. The leaues and the Å¿teales are of a Å¿ad greene like vnto RuÅ¿Å¿hes.

div.head: 10. Red Doggs teeth.
div.p: THe coloures of the flowers of Doggs teeth, are of tvvo dvvers Å¿ortes, that Å¿preade abroade theire leaues at the Å¿onne ryÅ¿inge. The firÅ¿t â¢â¢â¢ e of theÅ¿e is of a light purple or lack coloure, Å¿hadowed vvith a Å¿adder lack the Å¿priggs are white vvith little knopes, of a Å¿ad purple colour almoÅ¿t black, the clapper is a lightgreene.

div.head: VVhite Doggs teeth.
div.p: THe other flower is perfect white, and Å¿haddowed with lambeÅ¿black, hav nge Å¿ometymes certaine little Å¿potts of omber or of a very Å¿ad yellow, the laggs are rounded with Å¿ad omber, and topt with a little white vnder the omber, in the middle of thoÅ¿e Iaggs there ariÅ¿eth a manner of a clapper of a pale greene, Å¿hadowed with greene, and topt with maÅ¿ticote. The Å¿teale there of is a Å¿ad red, of lack, oker and a little greene tempered all together, Å¿hadowed with a little omber the leaves are of a cypres greene, and are marked with Å¿potts of lack and Å¿affron mingled together, the outtermoÅ¿t parte of the leaffe is Å¿omewhat Å¿adder, and comonly throughout, they are as the Å¿potts are that are vvithin.

div.head: 11. Comon Grape flowers.
div.p: HEre is expreÅ¿Å¿ed three Å¿ortes or Å¿everall faÅ¿hions of the Grape flowers or grape Iacynthes. The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e hath a Å¿ad blew coloured flower, painted w th Å¿ad aÅ¿hcoloure, Å¿hadowed with lack moes and indigo, where in is to be obÅ¿erved that the vppermoÅ¿te flowers vvhich Å¿tand at the top aboue Å¿hew Å¿omewhat lighter, and the ondermoÅ¿t muÅ¿t be vvhite vpon the edges but thoÅ¿e that are not fully blowne and open, needed to be made white vpon the edges.

div.head: Skie coloured Grape flovvers.

div.head: The tranÅ¿lator to the Readers, or practiÅ¿ioners.
div.p: THe Curteous practiÅ¿ioner Å¿hall pleaÅ¿e to vnderÅ¿tand, that theÅ¿e beinge (by earneÅ¿t requeÅ¿t) coÌmitted to mee to be tranÅ¿ta â¢ ed, and the names of the colours Å¿o much differinge from the originall language, that neither by Å¿earch of bookes, not conference with painters, not marchants beyonde the Å¿eas, could Å¿ufficientlie expreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ame to an EngliÅ¿hmans vnderÅ¿tandinge. Yet by Å¿ome that made profeÅ¿Å¿ion of that arte, beinge perÅ¿waded that they all had one generall name; whereof I my Å¿elffe know better, have done them all, or the moÅ¿t parte of them, to be vnderÅ¿toode of any EngliÅ¿hman, onely in one coloure which the dutchmen call Schijt-geel which tranÅ¿lated Å¿ignifieth a Å¿h â¢ tter yellow. I have in place thereof (becauÅ¿e of not offendinge modeÅ¿t eares) called it throughout the whole booke a Å¿ad yellow. It is that which the Lattines, french, and Å¿paniÅ¿h, call Buxus, that is box coloure, which is a â¢ ad or dead lyke yellow. Thus committing you to the protection and direction of the father of all goed Å¿piritts, I reÅ¿t.
